OBSERVATIONS: Use when customer has more than one device

A high-price event indicator light was provided on customer dryers.  Customers were given the choice to configure their dryers to be more or less sensitive to price signal.  Customers who chose low sensitivity had their dryers light turn on when the price was more than 1 sigma above the daily average price.  Customers who chose high sensitivity has their dryer`s light turn on when the price was above the daily average price.

DESCRIPTION: Command overridden by customer? [0 = NO, 1 = YES]
Dryer ON or OFF [0 = OFF, 1 = ON]

OBSERVATIONS: Thermostats establish the bid price using a k-factor that the customer can control, ranging from most comfort to most economy.  The k-factor is also used to adjust the thermostat setpoint based on the clearing price.  Customer can set multiple occupancy modes, each of which has specified cooling and heating temperatures.  The desired temperature is preferred temperature setting when the load control strategy is inactive.  The minimum and maximum temperatures define the range of temperature the load control strategy is allowed to use to curtail load.

DESCRIPTION: Demand response setting [0 = comfort, 2 = normal, 4 = economy]

OBSERVATIONS: Hotwater heater can be configured to curtail with a probability R = k/σ Erf[(P<sub>clear</sub>,P<sub>mean</sub>,σ)-1/2].  Values of k=0 disabled curtailment.

DESCRIPTION: Command overridden by customer? [0 = NO, 1 = YES]
